conclusion: To find the resultant Ampere force on the three resistance wires, we need to consider the Ampere force on each wire individually and then sum them up.
The figure shows an equilateral triangular conductor frame composed of uniform resistance wires placed perpendicular to a magnetic field. Points A and B are connected to a power supply.
The wire AB is perpendicular to the magnetic field.
The Ampere force on a wire in a magnetic field is given by F = BIL, where I is the current, L is the length of the wire, and B is the magnetic field strength.
Since AB is part of an equilateral triangle, its sides are equal, and the length of each side is s.
The current I is constant, and the magnetic field B is uniform.
The Ampere force on AB is F_AB = BIL.
The wire BC is also perpendicular to the magnetic field.
Since BC is part of an equilateral triangle, its sides are equal, and the length of each side is s.
The Ampere force on BC is F_BC = BIL.
The wire AC is also perpendicular to the magnetic field.
Since AC is part of an equilateral triangle, its sides are equal, and the length of each side is s.
The Ampere force on AC is F_AC = BIL.
The Ampere force on each wire is F_AB = F_BC = F_AC.
Since the current I is constant, the Ampere force on each wire is proportional to the length of the wire.
The Ampere force on each wire is F = BIL.
The resultant Ampere force on the three resistance wires is the sum of the individual Ampere forces.
Since the current I is constant, the resultant Ampere force is F = 3BIL.
The magnitude of the resultant Ampere force on the three resistance wires is 3BIL.
